conclusion: Pure practical reason has primacy over speculative reason because it can determine the will and postulate objects (God, freedom, immortality) that speculative reason can only think but not know
The fundamental principle of morality is given a priori as an unconditional, apodictically certain fact of pure reason, not derived from experience
So act that the maxim of your will could always hold at the same time as a principle in a giving of universal law
Freedom in the positive sense of autonomy is the necessary condition (ratio essendi) for the existence of the moral law
The moral law is how we become aware of our freedom (ratio cognoscendi)
While theoretical reason cannot prove freedom, practical reason necessitates its reality as a postulate for morality
The object of pure practical reason is the good and the evil, defined strictly in relation to the moral law, not antecedent to it
The moral law is a formal principle—a law of the form of maxims (their universality), not a law dictating specific ends or content
To apply the moral law to natural actions, we use the understanding's concept of a law of nature as a type or schema
The sole legitimate incentive for moral action is respect (Achtung) for the moral law—a feeling caused by reason itself, not a pathological feeling
Respect for the moral law humiliates our self-conceit (Eigendünkel) by striking down the pretensions of our sensible inclinations
The summum bonum (highest good) is constituted by virtue (worthiness to be happy) combined with happiness proportionate to that virtue
Virtue is the supreme good (supremum bonum)—the unconditioned condition of the summum bonum—but not the complete good
There is an apparent contradiction between the pursuit of virtue and the pursuit of happiness, as they are not causally connected in the world of sense
The summum bonum is possible only if we postulate the immortality of the soul and the existence of God
God, freedom, and immortality are postulates of pure practical reason—theoretical propositions necessitated as practically necessary presuppositions of obeying the moral law
Moral perfection (holiness) is required by the law but unattainable for a finite being, hence we must postulate an endless temporal progression (immortality)
A necessary being with supreme causality must be postulated as the ground of the exact correspondence between virtue and happiness
Belief in God and immortality is a matter of pure rational faith, grounded in practical necessity, not theoretical demonstration
The moral proof of God's existence demonstrates that belief in God is a necessary condition for coherently willing the summum bonum
Through its postulates, practical reason gives objective (though only practical) reality to ideas that for speculative reason were merely problematic
A will determined by its own law (the moral law) is autonomous; a will determined by any external object, desire, or authority is heteronomous
Only categorical imperatives (unconditional oughts) are moral; hypothetical imperatives are rules of skill or prudence
A practical law is objectively valid for all rational beings; a maxim is a subjective principle of volition
Moral principles are formal (concerned with the law's form); all material principles (based on an object of desire) are empirical and cannot found a moral law
We must conceive ourselves as belonging to an intelligible world (noumenal) governed by laws of freedom, and a sensible world (phenomenal) governed by natural causality
Rational beings are persons (ends in themselves); non-rational beings are things (means only)
The only thing good without qualification is a good will—a will whose maxims conform to the moral law
The moral worth of an action lies not in its effect but in the principle of the will (the maxim) from which it is done
For finite rational beings who have inclinations, the moral law presents itself as a duty—a necessitation or constraint
Virtue is the strength of a human being's maxims in fulfilling his duty—the fortitude to resist inclinations contrary to the law
Any ethical system making happiness (even the general welfare) the foundation is heteronomous and fails to capture the unconditional nature of moral obligation
Freedom is transcendental ideality but practical reality—as a theoretical concept it is an idea of reason; as a practical concept it is a real property of our will
The will is a kind of causality belonging to living beings insofar as they are rational
The moral law is not just a rule but an active power to cause action independently of sensibility
Consciousness of the moral law is undeniable—any attempt to doubt it already presupposes a moral standard
Unlike the categories of theoretical reason, the moral law needs no deduction because it is a fact of reason
All principles based on experience (happiness, moral sense, education, civil constitution) are unfit to serve as the foundation of moral laws
Perfection as a concept, if not defined morally, is empty and cannot serve as a first moral principle
The conflict between natural causality and freedom is resolved by viewing the same subject from two perspectives: as phenomenon (determined) and as noumenon (free)
The moral law is given by reason itself a priori—it is not a discovery from anthropology or psychology
Pure practical reason fills a gap in the critical system by giving content to the ideas of reason that the first Critique left empty
The incentive of pure practical reason must be pure—it cannot involve any sensuous desire or fear of punishment or hope of reward
To will in accordance with the moral law is to will the final end which reason connects with it—the summum bonum
It is not happiness in general but happiness proportionate to virtue that is willed as part of the summum bonum
The postulates assert the actual existence of God and an immortal soul, but only from a practical point of view
There is only one human reason, used theoretically and practically, with its practical use having primacy in the sphere of ends
The moral law brooks no rival determining grounds and demands unconditional submission
The method of pure practical reason begins with the analysis of ordinary moral consciousness and ascends to its supreme principle
All knowledge begins with experience, but not all knowledge arises from experience
Knowledge requires the synthesis of sensory intuitions with conceptual categories supplied by the understanding
The mind is not a passive recipient of impressions but actively structures experience according to its own forms
Objective knowledge is possible only because the mind imposes necessary conditions on all possible experience
Knowledge has two stems: sensibility (which provides intuitions) and understanding (which provides concepts)
Neither intuitions without concepts nor concepts without intuitions can yield knowledge
The proper object of human knowledge is appearances (phenomena), not things as they are in themselves
Certainty in knowledge comes not from correspondence with external reality but from the necessary structures of cognition itself
A priori knowledge is knowledge that is independent of all experience and necessarily universal
The marks of a priori knowledge are strict necessity and unrestricted universality
Pure a priori knowledge contains no empirical admixture whatsoever
Mathematics provides paradigmatic examples of pure a priori knowledge
The principles of pure understanding (e.g., causality) are known a priori
A priori knowledge is possible because the mind supplies the forms under which all experience must be organized
The a priori is not innate in the sense of being temporally prior to experience, but is logically independent of experience
A priori truths cannot be refuted by experience because they are conditions for the possibility of experience itself
Space and time, as forms of intuition, are known a priori
A posteriori knowledge is knowledge that can only be established through experience
A posteriori judgments are contingent—their negations are logically possible
Empirical knowledge is always particular and can never achieve strict universality
Natural science contains a posteriori elements insofar as it describes particular regularities in nature
The content of perception is given a posteriori, though its form is a priori
A posteriori knowledge depends on the actual course of experience and could have been otherwise
Inductive generalizations, being a posteriori, can never achieve apodictic certainty
The specific laws of nature are known a posteriori, though the general principle that nature has laws is known a priori
In analytic judgments, the predicate concept is contained within the subject concept
Analytic judgments are explicative—they clarify but do not extend knowledge
The principle of contradiction is the supreme principle of all analytic judgments
Analytic judgments are knowable a priori because their truth depends solely on the meanings of their terms
Analytic truths cannot be denied without self-contradiction
Analytic judgments, though certain, are cognitively empty—they tell us nothing about the world
The negation of an analytic truth is self-contradictory and therefore necessarily false
In synthetic judgments, the predicate concept lies outside the subject concept
Synthetic judgments are ampliative—they genuinely extend our knowledge
Synthetic a posteriori judgments are justified by experience
The revolutionary question of the Critique is: How are synthetic a priori judgments possible?
Mathematical truths are synthetic because the predicate is not logically contained in the subject
"7 + 5 = 12" is synthetic because the concept of 12 is not contained in the concepts of 7, 5, and addition
The principles of pure natural science (e.g., every event has a cause) are synthetic a priori
Synthetic a priori judgments are possible because they express the necessary conditions for any possible experience
Metaphysics, if it is to be a science, must consist of synthetic a priori judgments
A transcendental argument demonstrates the necessary conditions for the possibility of experience or knowledge
Transcendental arguments proceed regressively from an undeniable fact to its necessary presuppositions
The validity of the categories is established by showing that without them unified experience would be impossible
Transcendental arguments do not prove that things are a certain way, but that we must think them as being that way
The transcendental deduction shows that the categories have objective validity for all possible experience
Transcendental arguments establish truths that are neither merely logical nor merely empirical
The argument for the synthetic unity of apperception is paradigmatically transcendental
Transcendental proofs cannot be dogmatic demonstrations but must show the indispensability of certain concepts
Space and time are the a priori forms of sensible intuition—conditions under which objects can be given to us
The categories of the understanding are conditions under which objects can be thought
The transcendental unity of apperception is the supreme condition of all knowledge
The "I think" must be able to accompany all my representations
The schematism mediates between pure concepts and sensible intuitions
Transcendental imagination synthesizes the manifold of intuition according to the categories
Without the threefold synthesis (apprehension, reproduction, recognition), no coherent experience is possible
The principles of pure understanding (Axioms of Intuition, Anticipations of Perception, Analogies of Experience, Postulates of Empirical Thought) are constitutive of experience
Causality is a transcendental condition—every event must have a cause, not as a fact about the world, but as a condition for experiencing any event at all
The empirical self is the self as it appears in inner sense—a temporal sequence of mental states
The transcendental self (transcendental ego) is the logical subject of all representations, not itself an object of knowledge
The "I think" is a purely formal unity, not a substantial soul
Rational psychology commits a paralogism by treating the transcendental subject as a knowable substance
We cannot have theoretical knowledge of the soul's immortality, simplicity, or substantiality
The self that appears in inner sense is phenomenal, subject to the form of time
Personal identity is not given by a persisting substance but by the synthetic unity of apperception
The noumenal self (if there is one) would be outside time and thus free from natural causation
Self-knowledge is limited to how we appear to ourselves, not how we are in ourselves
The thinking subject cannot cognize itself as it is in itself, only as it appears
Phenomena are objects as they appear to us, conditioned by the forms of intuition and categories of understanding
Noumena are things as they are in themselves, independent of our cognitive apparatus
We can have no positive knowledge of noumena; the concept serves as a limiting concept
The noumenal/phenomenal distinction prevents us from confusing appearances with things in themselves
To say something is a phenomenon is not to say it is an illusion—phenomena are empirically real
Noumena in the negative sense are simply things considered apart from our mode of intuiting them
The positive concept of noumena (objects of intellectual intuition) is problematic for us, since we lack such intuition
The distinction between noumena and phenomena is transcendental, not empirical
Empirical realism (phenomena are real) is compatible with transcendental idealism (phenomena are mind-dependent)
The errors of traditional metaphysics arise from treating phenomenal predicates as applicable to noumena
The categories are pure concepts of the understanding that apply to objects of possible experience
There are exactly twelve categories, derived from the logical forms of judgment
The categories of Quantity are: Unity, Plurality, Totality
The categories of Quality are: Reality, Negation, Limitation
The categories of Relation are: Inherence/Subsistence (substance), Causality/Dependence, Community (reciprocity)
The categories of Modality are: Possibility/Impossibility, Existence/Non-existence, Necessity/Contingency
The categories have no content apart from their application to sensible intuition
Unschematized categories are mere logical forms with no cognitive significance
The schemata translate categories into temporal terms applicable to experience
Substance is schematized as permanence in time; causality as succession according to a rule
The categories are not derived from experience but are presupposed by it
Kant's categories are epistemological/transcendental; Aristotle's are ontological/metaphysical
Aristotle's categories classify beings; Kant's categories classify ways of thinking about objects
Aristotle derived his categories unsystematically; Kant derives his from the table of judgments
Aristotle's category of substance refers to independently existing things; Kant's refers to the logical subject of predication and the schema of permanence
Kant criticizes Aristotle for mixing empirical concepts (e.g., motion, place) with pure concepts
Kant's table claims completeness on principled grounds; Aristotle's list is rhapsodic
Aristotle's categories apply to things in themselves; Kant's apply only to phenomena
Both Kant and Aristotle recognize substance and relation as fundamental, but interpret them differently
Kant transforms Aristotelian metaphysics into critical epistemology
Reason inevitably generates ideas that transcend all possible experience (God, soul, cosmos)
The transcendental ideas are regulative, not constitutive—they guide inquiry but do not yield knowledge
The antinomies arise when reason tries to think the unconditioned totality of conditions
Traditional metaphysics fails because it applies categories beyond the bounds of possible experience
Theoretical reason cannot prove or disprove the existence of God, freedom, or immortality
The critique of reason is reason's self-examination of its own powers and limits
Speculative metaphysics must be replaced by critical metaphysics—the study of the conditions of knowledge
Reason's illusions are natural and unavoidable but must be recognized as illusions
The proper use of transcendental ideas is regulative: to seek ever greater unity and completeness in knowledge
Attempting to know noumena produces only dialectical illusion, not genuine cognition
God is conceived as the ens realissimum—the being possessing all perfections
God is the transcendental ideal—the concept of a being that grounds all possibility
Theoretical reason cannot determine whether God exists or what God's nature is
The ontological argument fails because existence is not a real predicate
The cosmological argument illicitly infers from contingent existence to a necessary being
The physico-theological (design) argument at most proves an architect, not a creator ex nihilo
All proofs of God's existence ultimately rest on the invalid ontological argument
God, as a noumenon, cannot be an object of theoretical cognition
The concept of God is practically necessary as the postulate of moral reason
If God exists, God exists as a thing in itself, not as an appearance in space and time
We cannot apply the categories to God because they function only in relation to sensible intuition
Statements about God's attributes are analogical, not literal—we use concepts from experience symbolically
God is not subject to temporal succession or spatial location
God's causality (if any) would be noumenal, not phenomenal—not subject to natural laws
The noumenal status of God means theoretical agnosticism: we cannot know, only think, God
God as noumenon is compatible with the thoroughgoing causal determinism of the phenomenal world
The transcendental ideal represents God as the ground of all possibility—that from which all determinations derive
God, conceived as the ens realissimum, is the substrate from which all finite realities are limitations
The conception of God as noumenal ground is regulative: we are to think of the world as if grounded in a supreme reality
The intelligible (noumenal) ground of appearances might be conceived as divine
Speculative theology cannot establish that there is such a substrate, only that reason naturally forms this idea
The concept of God as noumenal ground helps unify our conception of nature under one principle
Creation ex nihilo is a temporal concept inapplicable to a noumenal God
If God grounds the world, it is not through a temporal act but through a timeless ontological relation
The noumenal substrate constitutes appearances in the sense of grounding their possibility, not manufacturing them
God as constituting ground differs from a deistic creator who initiates a causal series
The relationship between noumenal ground and phenomenal world is not itself a causal relationship in the empirical sense
Traditional theological language of creation must be understood analogically or symbolically
Religion within the limits of reason alone focuses on morality, not revelation or miracle
The moral law is the authentic core of religious teaching
Historical religions are vehicles for moral truths accessible to reason
Rational religion requires no church, ritual, or clergy—only the moral disposition
The idea of a moral community (ethical commonwealth) is the true church
Statutory religions are legitimate only insofar as they promote morality
Religious doctrines must be interpreted to accord with moral reason
Miracles, if they occur, add nothing to our moral duties
Dogmatic religion accepts doctrines on authority without rational justification
Rational religion accepts only what can be established by moral reason
Dogmatic religion subordinates morality to theological commands; rational religion subordinates theology to morality
True religion is moral religion—recognition of duties as divine commands
Dogmatic religion emphasizes grace, revelation, and cult; rational religion emphasizes virtue and moral effort
Ecclesiastical faith (statutory religion) should gradually give way to pure rational faith
Religious disputes arise from confusing the vehicle (historical religion) with the essence (moral law)
Rational religion is universal; dogmatic religions are parochial
Morality is grounded in reason alone, not in empirical desires, sentiments, or consequences
The moral law is categorical—it commands unconditionally, regardless of inclinations
Only a good will is unconditionally good; all other goods are conditional
The good will is good not because of what it accomplishes but because of its principle of volition
Duty is the necessity of acting from respect for the moral law
Actions have moral worth only when done from duty, not merely in conformity with duty
Moral principles must be universal and necessary, not derived from particular circumstances
Happiness is not the ground of morality but may be its consequence under a moral world order
The categorical imperative is the supreme principle of morality, derivable from reason alone
Act only according to that maxim you can will to be a universal law (first formulation)
Treat humanity, in yourself and others, always as an end, never merely as a means (humanity formula)
Act as a legislating member of a kingdom of ends (autonomy formula)
All formulations of the categorical imperative express the same fundamental principle from different perspectives
Moral autonomy is the capacity of rational beings to give themselves the moral law
Heteronomous ethics (grounded in desire, happiness, divine command) cannot yield genuinely binding obligations
Practical reason is self-legislating—it does not receive the law from outside but enacts it
The moral law is a synthetic a priori practical principle
Moral obligation is necessitation of an imperfectly rational will by the moral law
For a perfectly rational being, morality would not take the form of obligation or imperative
Human beings experience the moral law as constraint because they have sensuous inclinations
Obligation implies freedom: ought implies can
Moral obligation is unconditional—not hypothetical upon any desired end
The feeling of respect is the subjective effect of the moral law on sensibility
Moral obligation binds all rational beings as such, not merely humans
The bindingness of duty is not contingent on reward or punishment
The only legitimate form of government is republican—based on freedom, equality, and the rule of law
Political authority must be exercised according to publicly promulgated laws
Citizens must have equal rights under the law regardless of birth or status
Freedom requires that no one can be coerced except according to universal law
The social contract is not historical but an idea of reason legitimizing the state
Despotism conflates legislative and executive power; republicanism separates them
There is no right to revolution, though illegitimate governments should be reformed
International relations should be governed by a federation of free states aiming at perpetual peace
Property rights are grounded in the rational will and must be secured by civil law
Original acquisition of property must be compatible with the freedom of all others
The state must enforce contracts and protect property as conditions of external freedom
Economic relations must respect persons as ends in themselves, not exploit them as mere means
A just economic order allows all citizens the conditions for exercising their freedom
Extreme inequality that denies some persons the means of independence is morally suspect
The solar system originated from a rotating nebula that gradually condensed under gravitational attraction
The initial nebula was a diffuse cloud of gas and dust distributed uniformly through space
Gravitational collapse caused rotation to accelerate and the nebula to flatten into a disk
Planets formed from the accretion of matter in rings separated from the central mass
The nebular hypothesis explains the coplanar orbits and uniform rotational direction of planets
The same natural laws that govern the cosmos now sufficed to produce it from initial chaos
No supernatural intervention is required to explain the structure of the solar system
Space is not a property of things in themselves but the form of outer intuition
Space is empirically real—it applies to all objects of outer experience
Space is transcendentally ideal—it does not pertain to things apart from our mode of intuition
Space is a pure a priori intuition, not a general concept abstracted from experience
We can represent empty space but cannot represent the absence of space
The singularity and infinity of space prove it is an intuition, not a concept
Geometry is possible as synthetic a priori knowledge because space is a pure form of intuition
Space is not a substance, a relation among substances, or an absolute container
The ideality of space means that spatial properties do not characterize things in themselves

topic: Time as Form of Inner Sense
conclusion: Time is the form of inner sense—the form under which we intuit ourselves and our mental states
Time is also mediately the form of all appearances, since all representations occur in time
Time is empirically real for all appearances but transcendentally ideal
Time is not an independent reality but a subjective condition of intuition
Simultaneity and succession are temporal relations that hold only for phenomena
The unity of time grounds the possibility of representing objects as enduring or changing
Time, like space, is a pure a priori intuition, presupposed by all empirical representations
Arithmetic is grounded in the successive synthesis of units in time
Things in themselves are not in time; temporal predicates apply only to appearances
Mathematical propositions are synthetic a priori—they extend knowledge and are necessarily true
Geometry is grounded in the pure intuition of space and applies necessarily to spatial objects
Arithmetic depends on the successive synthesis of units in time—it is not merely analytic
Mathematical certainty derives from the construction of concepts in pure intuition
Mathematical truths are not discovered by analyzing concepts but by constructing objects in intuition
The apodictic certainty of mathematics is explained by its grounding in pure intuition
Applied mathematics describes the phenomenal world because phenomena must conform to space and time
Mathematics is not about things in themselves but about the formal structure of possible experience
The universality of mathematical truths reflects the universality of the forms of intuition
Mathematical reasoning is synthetic because it proceeds by construction, not mere conceptual analysis
The Copernican revolution in philosophy holds that objects must conform to our cognition, not cognition to objects
Transcendental philosophy investigates not objects but our mode of cognizing objects insofar as this is possible a priori
The synthetic unity of the manifold of intuition is the ground of the identity of apperception itself
Cognition involves both receptivity (sensibility) and spontaneity (understanding)
The understanding cannot intuit, and the senses cannot think; only through their union does knowledge arise
Experience is itself a species of knowledge that involves understanding, whose rule I must presuppose in myself before objects are given to me
The original synthetic unity of apperception is objective because it is the condition of all knowledge of objects
All empirical consciousness has a necessary relation to a transcendental consciousness preceding all particular experience
The thoroughgoing affinity of appearances is a necessary consequence of the synthesis according to concepts
Cognition and its object must agree; an object is that in the concept of which the manifold of a given intuition is united
Pure reason contains the principles for knowing something absolutely a priori
The a priori origin of principles can be established by showing that without them experience itself would be impossible
A priori cognitions are those with which no empirical element is intermixed
The possibility of experience is itself the a priori ground of the objective validity of the categories
We can know a priori of things only what we ourselves put into them
The synthetic a priori is not mysterious once we recognize that the mind legislates to nature
A priori principles are not rules abstracted from experience but rules that make experience possible
The understanding is the source of the laws of nature with respect to their formal structure
Pure intuitions and pure concepts are the a priori elements of all human cognition
A priori knowledge is distinguished not by its temporal origin but by its independence from any particular experience
Perception is empirical consciousness—consciousness accompanied by sensation
The matter of appearance—that which corresponds to sensation—is given a posteriori
Empirical intuition is possible only through pure intuition of space and time
A posteriori judgments require the testimony of experience for their justification
The particular laws of nature cannot be derived from the categories alone; they must be learned empirically
Experience teaches us that something is constituted thus and so, but not that it could not be otherwise
Sensation is the effect of an object upon the faculty of representation, insofar as we are affected by it
All our intuition is nothing but the representation of appearance; the things we intuit are not in themselves what we intuit them as being
The real in appearances (corresponding to sensation) always has an intensive magnitude or degree
In analytic judgments, the connection of subject and predicate is thought through identity
Analytic judgments rest entirely on the principle of contradiction
All analytic judgments are a priori, even when their concepts are empirical
Analytic judgments require no appeal to experience for their justification, only reflection on concepts
The predicate of an affirmative analytic judgment is covertly contained in the subject concept
Analytic judgments clarify but do not amplify our cognition
Logical analysis of concepts yields only analytic truths
The truth of an analytic judgment is guaranteed by the law of non-contradiction alone
Analytic judgments are epistemically trivial but logically necessary
Synthetic judgments require a third thing beyond subject and predicate to mediate their connection
In synthetic a posteriori judgments, experience provides the mediating third term
In synthetic a priori judgments, pure intuition provides the mediating third term
The principle that every event has a cause is synthetic because causation is not contained in the concept of event
Synthetic a priori judgments are the proper subject matter of transcendental philosophy
The possibility of synthetic a priori judgments is the general problem of pure reason
All judgments of experience are synthetic because they go beyond what the concept of the subject contains
The ampliative character of synthetic judgments makes them indispensable for genuine knowledge
Synthetic unity differs from analytic unity as combination differs from mere analysis
The synthesis of apprehension, reproduction, and recognition grounds all synthetic cognition
Transcendental proofs must show that something is a condition of the possibility of experience as such
The transcendental deduction answers the quid juris: by what right do we apply pure concepts to objects?
A transcendental argument is not a causal explanation but a demonstration of necessary presuppositions
The objectivity of the categories is secured by showing they are conditions of any unified consciousness
Transcendental arguments establish the validity of concepts for possible experience, not for things in themselves
The unity of consciousness requires that the manifold of intuition be subject to the categories
Transcendental arguments reveal that certain skeptical positions are self-undermining
The refutation of idealism is a transcendental argument: inner experience presupposes outer experience
Transcendental reasoning shows that denying certain principles makes coherent experience impossible
The understanding itself is the lawgiver of nature—not of empirical laws, but of the universal form of law
Nature, as the sum of appearances, is possible only in the unity of apperception
The objective unity of self-consciousness is the condition of all knowledge of objects
Synthesis is the act of putting different representations together and comprehending their manifoldness in one cognition
The categories are functions of unity in judgment applied to the synthesis of intuitions
The transcendental schema of substance is permanence of the real in time
The schema of causality is the real upon which, whenever posited, something else always follows
The schema of community is the coexistence of determinations of one substance with those of another according to a universal rule
The schema of possibility is the agreement of the synthesis of representations with the conditions of time in general
The schema of actuality is existence at a determinate time
The schema of necessity is the existence of an object at all times
The I is simple in representation, but this does not establish that the soul is a simple substance
The transcendental subject is the logical correlate of all concepts, not an intuitable object
Inner sense gives us ourselves only as we appear, not as we are in ourselves
The unity of consciousness does not reveal the nature of the thinking being
From the bare I think nothing can be inferred about the substantiality, simplicity, or permanence of the soul
The identity of the subject of which I am conscious in all my representations is not the identity of substance
The soul, as object of inner sense, is phenomenal; what it is in itself is unknowable
Rational psychology's errors arise from treating the transcendental unity of apperception as an object of cognition
Self-affection means that we intuit ourselves only through the way we are affected internally
The I think expresses an indeterminate empirical intuition, not a determinate cognition of a noumenal self
The concept of a noumenon is a boundary concept—it limits sensibility without positing anything beyond it
Phenomena are not mere illusions; they are empirically real objects given under the forms of intuition
Transcendental idealism maintains that space and time are not properties of things in themselves
Empirical realism affirms that external objects are real as phenomena within space
The thing in itself is not a different thing from the appearance but the same thing considered differently
We know phenomena as they appear but not what they are in themselves
Noumena cannot be positively characterized because all our determinate concepts are schematized for sensibility
The distinction between phenomena and noumena saves both science and morality
The phenomenal world is deterministic; the noumenal realm allows room for freedom
To confuse phenomena with things in themselves is the source of transcendental illusion
The categories are pure concepts originating solely in the understanding
Without application to intuition, categories are merely logical functions without content
The categories can be derived systematically from the logical forms of judgment
Each category corresponds to a specific form of synthesis through which the manifold is united
Categories of quantity determine the extensive magnitude of intuitions
Categories of quality determine the intensive magnitude (degree) of sensations
Categories of relation determine the connection of perceptions in one consciousness
Categories of modality do not add to the concept of an object but express its relation to cognition
Mathematical categories (quantity, quality) are constitutive of intuitions
Dynamical categories (relation, modality) are constitutive of the existence of objects in relation to each other
Each category has a corresponding schema that temporalizes the pure concept for application to experience
Kant transforms Aristotle's categories from descriptive classifications to transcendental conditions
Aristotle lists ten categories without a principle of completeness; Kant claims systematic derivation
Aristotle's categories describe what is; Kant's describe how we must think what is
Kant rejects Aristotle's inclusion of time, place, position, and state as mixing pure and empirical concepts
The Kantian category of relation encompasses what Aristotle distributed among several categories
For Aristotle, substance is primary being; for Kant, substance is the schema of permanence underlying change
Kant regards Aristotle's categories as lacking unity of principle and merely empirically assembled
The critical transformation of the categories removes them from metaphysics to epistemology
Both Kant and Aristotle agree that substance and attribute are fundamental, though they interpret them differently
The ideas of reason (soul, world, God) have no corresponding object in possible experience
The cosmological antinomies arise from treating the world as a thing in itself with determinate totality
The thesis of each antinomy represents rationalist dogmatism; the antithesis represents empiricist dogmatism
In mathematical antinomies, both thesis and antithesis are false because they presuppose a completed infinite series
In dynamical antinomies, both thesis and antithesis can be true because they apply to different realms
Transcendental illusion is natural and unavoidable—reason necessarily generates it
The ideas of reason have legitimate regulative use in guiding the understanding toward systematic unity
To mistake regulative principles for constitutive principles is to fall into dogmatic metaphysics
The dialectic of pure reason reveals that unaided speculation cannot resolve ultimate questions
The proper business of reason is not to extend knowledge beyond experience but to secure it within experience
The concept of God as ens realissimum represents the sum total of all predicates of things in general
The transcendental ideal hypostasizes this concept into an individual being
The three speculative proofs of God (ontological, cosmological, physico-theological) all fail
The ontological argument confuses logical with real predicates
One hundred actual dollars contain not a penny more than one hundred possible dollars
The cosmological argument covertly employs the ontological argument by moving from necessary being to most real being
The argument from design cannot establish an infinite, necessary, omnipotent creator
Theoretical reason can neither prove nor disprove God's existence
The concept of God remains a legitimate idea of reason though not an object of knowledge
God, if existing, would not be subject to the conditions of time and space
We cannot know whether there is a being corresponding to the concept of God
All predicates we apply to God are derived from experience and applied only analogically
Divine omniscience, omnipotence, and benevolence cannot be theoretically demonstrated
God's existence as noumenon is compatible with the determinism of phenomena
A noumenal God would be causa noumenon—a cause not subject to empirical causation
We must think God under categories, but this does not yield knowledge of God
The noumenal character of God means rational theology yields only faith, not science
The ideal of pure reason represents the idea of a ground of thoroughgoing determination
All finite things are determinations or limitations of the one unlimited reality
This conception does not prove a supreme being exists but shows how reason naturally forms the idea
The ens realissimum grounds all possibility by containing all predicates primitively
Negative predicates (non-being, limitation) presuppose positive predicates in the unlimited being
The world of appearances might be grounded in an intelligible substrate inaccessible to theoretical cognition
Reason seeks the unconditioned ground of all conditioned existence, though it cannot know this ground
Noumenal causality is not successive—it does not operate in time as phenomenal causation does
If God grounds the phenomenal world, this grounding is ontological, not temporal
The concept of creation in time cannot apply to a timeless noumenal ground
The distinction between phenomenal succession and noumenal grounding prevents anthropomorphic theology
God as constituting ground differs from the watchmaker God of deistic natural theology
The noumenal ground of appearances is not a first member of a temporal series
The moral law within us is the authentic voice of the divine
Ecclesiastical faith requires interpretation through pure moral religion
Prayer, ritual, and observance have value only as means to moral improvement
Religion is the recognition of all our duties as divine commands
Radical evil is the innate propensity to subordinate moral law to self-love
Moral regeneration requires a revolution in disposition, a rebirth of character
The historical person of a moral teacher is less important than the moral archetype he represents
The ethical community is the kingdom of God on earth—a union of persons under moral laws
Clericalism that substitutes observance for morality is pseudo-service to God
Rational religion derives its content from moral reason; dogmatic religion accepts revelation uncritically
The Bible should be read as a vehicle for moral truth, not as literal metaphysical doctrine
Miracles cannot add to moral duty, which is already completely determined by reason
Dogmatic religion makes salvation depend on belief; rational religion makes it depend on moral disposition
Rational religion is available to all rational beings as such; dogmatic religion is historically particular
The gradual progress of humanity is toward pure rational faith
Mysteries and sacraments must be interpreted morally or set aside
Dogmatic religion risks superstition; rational religion upholds human autonomy and dignity
The moral law commands categorically, not hypothetically
Hypothetical imperatives are conditional on some end; categorical imperatives are unconditional
All imperatives express an ought—the relation of objective laws of reason to a will not necessarily determined by them
A perfectly good will would act according to the moral law without experiencing it as imperative
The good will is the only unconditional good because all other goods can be misused
Talents, gifts, and fortune are good only when governed by a good will
Acting in conformity with duty is not the same as acting from duty
The shopkeeper who gives correct change from self-interest acts in conformity with duty but not from duty
Moral worth attaches only to actions done from respect for the moral law
Inclination, even benevolent inclination, has no moral worth unless it is subordinated to duty
The universalizability test determines whether a maxim is morally permissible
A maxim that cannot be universalized without contradiction is forbidden
Making a lying promise fails the universalizability test because universal lying would destroy the institution of promising
Suicide from self-love is contradictory because the same principle (self-love) would mandate both living and dying
Neglecting to develop talents is wrong because we cannot rationally will a world of universal idleness
Refusing to aid others in distress is wrong because we cannot will a world in which no one helps anyone
The humanity formula prohibits using persons merely as instruments
The dignity of rational beings places them above all price
Autonomy is the ground of the dignity of human and every rational nature
Heteronomy arises when the will seeks its law in any object outside itself
Moral necessitation arises because finite rational beings have inclinations that may conflict with reason
Obligation presupposes the possibility of acting otherwise—duty implies freedom
The binding force of the moral law does not derive from consequences or feelings
Respect for the moral law is a unique feeling produced by reason, not derived from sensibility
Duty is not a burden imposed from without but the expression of our rational nature
The moral law is legislative for all rational beings, not merely human beings
Perfect duties admit no exception in favor of inclination; imperfect duties allow latitude in fulfillment
The supreme principle of morality is the form of universal law commanded by reason
Civil society exists to secure the external freedom of each compatible with the freedom of all
The original contract is an idea of reason that legitimizes positive law
Laws must be such that they could have been consented to by all rational citizens
The sovereign represents the general united will, not private interests
Active citizenship requires economic independence; those dependent on others cannot vote
Punishment is justified solely by desert, not by deterrence or rehabilitation
The federation of free states would replace the lawless condition among nations with lawful relations
Perpetual peace is the final goal of all international right
A world republic may be ideal but a league of states is more practically attainable
The right to property is an external mine and thine established by civil law
Unilateral acquisition requires subsequent juridical validation by the civil condition
The state may regulate property for the common good while respecting acquired rights
A just state provides the juridical framework for economic activity but does not direct it
Contracts must be honored—pacta sunt servanda is a principle of right
Servitude and slavery violate the innate right to freedom and are absolutely impermissible
Each person has the right to seek economic independence through labor and exchange
The civil condition transforms provisional natural rights into secured peremptory rights
The nebular hypothesis exemplifies the power of mechanical explanation in cosmology
Kant proposed in 1755 that the universe developed from a primordial chaos by natural laws
Rotation and gravitational attraction explain the formation of the solar system without supernatural intervention
The disk shape of the Milky Way reflects its origin from a rotating nebula
Other nebulae are island universes—galaxies comparable to our own Milky Way
The laws of Newtonian mechanics suffice to account for cosmic evolution
Teleological order in nature need not imply an external designer—it can arise from mechanical principles
The nebular hypothesis illustrates that natural science explains phenomena without appealing to transcendent causes
Space is nothing other than the form of all appearances of outer sense
Space is represented as a given infinite magnitude—this marks it as intuition, not concept
Geometry constructs its objects in pure spatial intuition a priori
The apodicticity of geometry derives from the a priori status of space
If space were a thing in itself, geometry would be empirical and contingent
Leibniz erred in treating space as a confused representation of relations among things in themselves
Newton erred in treating space as an absolute container existing independently of things
The ideality of space dissolves the conflict between Leibnizian and Newtonian views
Spatial properties (shape, size, position) pertain to phenomena only, not to things in themselves
The pure intuition of space is the source of all geometrical constructions
Time is the form of inner sense—the mode under which the mind intuits its own states
All appearances whatsoever are in time, since all representations are states of the mind
Time is not something that exists in itself or inheres in things as an objective determination
The three modes of time are duration, succession, and coexistence
Time is the formal condition of all appearances in general
Change is possible only in time; without time, neither change nor permanence is representable
The permanence of substance is the schema of time with respect to duration
If time were a thing in itself, it would exist without any actual object
Time has only one dimension; different times are not simultaneous but successive
The infinity of time means that every determinate magnitude of time is possible only through limitations of one underlying time
Mathematical cognition is cognition from the construction of concepts
To construct a concept is to exhibit a priori the intuition corresponding to it
In geometry, construction proceeds in pure spatial intuition
Algebraic construction employs symbolic construction through characters representing magnitudes
Mathematical demonstrations exhibit their objects in intuition and thus yield synthetic knowledge
Philosophy cannot proceed by construction because philosophical concepts cannot be exhibited in pure intuition
The synthetic character of mathematics explains why mathematical discoveries are genuine extensions of knowledge
Mathematical axioms are immediately certain because they are grounded in pure intuition
Mathematical postulates are practical propositions for constructing figures
The necessity of mathematical truths follows from their grounding in the necessary forms of intuition
Mathematics achieves apodictic certainty because it deals with the necessary structure of appearances
The applicability of mathematics to nature is guaranteed because nature must conform to the forms of intuition
